text: I'm a realist when it comes to the
damage I'm living proof than anything
floats I bobbled like a cork in the
water and I spent the store a minute but
if we redid a house a day it would take
st. Bernard 74 years to get back what we
had mark madari faces that challenge
every day a lifelong resident of st.
Bernard Parish he now spends his days at
his old Catholic elementary school
running a base camp for the continuing
influx of Katrina volunteers eager to
help rebuild it's called Camp Hope and
and you know if we were just a personal
standpoint when I was 16 17 years old
let's say I can go to the beach and look
at girls in a bathing suit and float
with them I can come walk through
somebody else's mess and help with their
life back
that is that stuff this week Camp Hope
faces a bittersweet transition the
Katrina volunteers are being relocated
to make way for more than 300 BP workers
as part of the arrangement BP is
spending six hundred thousand dollars to
renovate the building ten days ago you
would have been overcome with the heat
and flies because we didn't have air
conditioned downstairs the upgrades have
been been shower facilities bad
facilities laundry facilities for now
Katrina volunteers and VP workers eat
lunch side-by-side this lunchroom scene
is the latest example of how the
building itself reflects the recent
history of st. Bernard a parish
devastated by Katrina mr. madari
remembers when this building was his
elementary school st. Louise de Marillac
miss chest aunt was my kindergarten
teacher miss Walsh was second grade
third grade was miss bro which attends
to my is being his fig since she yelled
at me and pulled on them Hurricane
Katrina hit in the late summer of two
thousand five and save Louise never
reopened the building SAT vacant for
years it still bears Katrina's markings
inside though it contains the visible
legacy of volunteer groups with helped
in the rebuilding of st. Bernard
there's a lot of need left here I don't
understand how it's been left this long
I was actually shocked when I came down
here and seeing all the concrete slabs
to all the people who may not ever come
back and now the former classrooms will
be the home for workers dealing with
another catastrophe one that is still
unfolding for mr. madari camp hopes
renovation is a mixed blessing I got ten
bags a grocery to carry in and somebody
offered to carry one end I need to help
so I'll take whatever way it comes in
this particular scenario bp's paying for
that help he may have caused the problem
I'm going to take to help because I
can't carry an attend bags of groceries
hell it's not yet known when the BP
workers will be leaving but once they're
gone the building will again house
Katrina volunteers and the volunteers
will be welcome in st. Bernard until
there is nothing more for them to do
for the New York Times this is dan Barry
